Peabody students getting in tune for
transposition to Hopkins: some notes,
quotes, and thoughts about new school
As a result of the recent
quasi-affiliation agreement
between Hopkins and the
Peabody Conservatory, Peabody
students will soon become visible
around Homewood, just as
Hopkins students will start to
appear around Mount Vernon
Place. Peabody should develop
closer ties with Hopkins than the
Other University affiliates (such
as SAIS and APL) because it's
closer and mostly undergraduate.
Peabody students, though, are
very different from the ordinary
Hopkins undergrad. Most
Hopkins students are continuing
their education to find a skill;
most Peabody students are
continuing their education to
perfect a skill, the performance
of music. The pressurized
Pre-professional Hopkins world
would seem foreign to them,just
iS playing a cello in a string
quartet for credit would seem
strange to a Hopkins pre-med.
For a brief look at the newest
members of what somebody
termed the "Hopkins
community," we recently visited
Peabody and talked with the
students about the affiliation.
"We weren't .really sure what
Was going on," she said,"because
we had heard from the Hopkins
students what was happening,
and when we came back from
our vacation all of a sudden they
told us we had merged." A
violinist working to receive her
Masters, she was sitting in a
lounge next to the Peabody
cafeteria. Like most of the

students we talked to, she
thought that the affiliation
between Hopkins and Peabody
was a real advantage. "Well, it
would be nice to have stronger
academics...Not only that, but
people have always missed
college life; there's none of it
here. How much could there be
in one city block?
"And also the diversity of
students...well, we just have
music students. That would be
nice, meeting other viewpoints,
other ideas." But because no one
is really sure what the affiliation
will amount to, she had a few
doubts." I think every one was a
little frightened, with Hopkins,
being what it is academically,
everybody would be put under
more stress in the non-music
subjects." As of yet, though, she
hasn't heard of any course or
requirement changes. "Really
I've heard very little; people are
just waiting to see what happens
next year. Right now, all we're
hearing is the benefits," she
laughed.
Tom Van Wagner, a
put his feelings
violinist ,
simply: "Well, I was glad." Van
Wagner and his roommate live
near Hopkins, so he was already
familiar with many of the
University's facilities. One thing
he would like to see is a shuttle
service between Peabody and
Hopkins, similar to the already
existing East Baltimore Campus
bus. "That way, if any of the
kids wanted to take advantage of
the teachers up at Hopkins, they
could just do it. They wouldn't

have to catch a city bus."
He looks forward to seeing
more interaction between
Peabody and Hopkins students.
"I've been getting kids together,
and we've been going up and
• playing basketball on Saturdays.
I think it would be nice if there
was a Hopkins group that could
come down here, say, during the
week or on weekends, and put
affairs on like they do up there,
because this place is very dead.
There's no pub, there's no social
clubs; there's nothing here,
except for the school."
To Eric Landers, the affiliation
"would probably be good,
especially for Peabody." One of
the most obvious ways Hopkins
could help Peabody in Landers'
view is purely physical. "The
buildings themselves are kind of
starting to fall apart. They're old,
and there are just dumb repairs
which aren't being done." He
mentioned that some of the
pianos were beginning to show
signs of wear.'" A lot of them
need overhauls, and they're not
getting them. A friend of mine
went to a recital two nights ago,
and during the recital, a hammer
broke on the piano. S000
musical....I •would hope that
there would be, a little money
coming from the Hopkins people,
especially their fund raisers.
Because at Peabody, they don't
get much."
Landers, a second -year
trombonist, was unsure of how
the affiliation would affect
course offerings. "What I have
been told is that Peabody

,
students will be able to attend
Hopkins courses, if they can cut
it. Probably there won't be too
many that do it anyway, because
most people want to practice. I
don't know if Hopkins students
wi.11 be coming down
here....Some people were worried
about Hopkins students coming
down here and polluting the
ensembles. Of course, that
wouldn't make much difference
anyway; they're only audition
groups. But that's the kind of
thing that was going around.
"I'm sure there are a lot of
students at Hopkins who were,
maybe while they were in high
school, maybe on an amateur
basis, interested in music, maybe
they have questions they could
ask us; I surely have numbers of
questions that I'd like to ask
Hopkins students. I just like to
sit around and shoot the shit
with a bunch of people.. hash stuff
out.
"I think the big thing is just
getting in with a big school like
Hopkins, it's going to attract
more people, and hopefully the
fundraising, to improve the plant,
make it bigger down here.
Because we're getting a lot more
people down here."
"I think it is a good idea," said
cellist Theresa Cardoza of the
merger, "Because Peabody is on
its way down financially. I don't
think Hopkins is getting that
much out of it, except that now
they have a big music
department; it seems to me
rather a favor that Hopkins took
us.
"Our academic courses here
are miserable, and I'm very glad
now that we will be able to take
Hopkins classes, and use the
library." Although Peabody
students have always been able to
take Hopkins courses, they've
had to pay extra. "This way we
get it free, and personally I don't
have that kind of money, to be
able to take Hopkins courses."

She looks fbrward to taking
courses at Hopkins, because the
academics at Peabody are, "very
poor, nothing challenging in the
least:
"I don't know what it would
be like, how (Hopkins and
Peabody) students will mix, but
hopefully they will...Peabody's a
very small school, you get to see
very few people, and it's only
one outlook, the musician's
outlook on life. I'd like to know
what other people think, that
type of thing.
"There's one thing I'm very
happy with: the administration
here has crushed the student
council, the student paper, things
like that, and hopefully with
Hopkins the administration will
he a little more fair, a little more
reasonable, and perhaps we'll be
able to have some student voice.
So I'm hoping that Hopkins will
be able to raise the quality of
Peabody's administration, and
our education."
Trumpeter Ted Jones felt that
for him the advantage would be
that "I'll be able to take courses
at Hopkins. I've been wanting to
for a year, but I couldn't without
paying. It's too bad they couldn't
do it sooner."
"A magnificent union of
material and spiritual forces
which should be very fruitful in
the future," was how Paul
Abturino termed the union. His
own aspiration was somewhat
more modestAhe looked forward
to "using the swimming pool." A
recent transfer to Peabody, he
didn't have a great deal to say,
because "I don't know that much
about it. I've never been to Johns
Hopkins, so I have no idea as to
their facilities." Now that the
Conservatory is becoming a part
of the University, he says that he
will probably come down to
Hopkins, "especially if there is a
shuttle bus set up in the fall."

ahead of the game upon joining

will to the curious here. Much
shuttling , therefore, between

appear likely for a while. The
calendars may soon be the same,
but the people will be following
them quite differently.
